Award.AwardTitle: Investigating Mechanisms of RNA Polymerase II Transcription and Regulation Using Single-molecule Fluorescence

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit: The process of mRNA synthesis (transcription) is a principle control point for regulating gene expression during growth, development, and normal cellular metabolism. The first step in transcription is formation of a complex of proteins at the promoter of the DNA template. The goal of this project is to investigate the assembly mechanism, dynamics, and heterogeneity of human transcription factor/DNA complexes, and how these parameters contribute to transcriptional control. This research will take advantage of single-molecule fluorescence techniques, which have emerged as essential contributors to revealing the dynamic behavior, conformational states, and heterogeneity of biological complexes, thus providing unprecedented insight into their function. Specifically, studies will investigate human HMGB1, a biologically essential architectural protein that facilitates the formation of protein/DNA complexes important in transcriptional regulation by dynamically binding and bending DNA. The mechanism by which HMGB1 binds and distorts DNA, and how this activity facilitates DNA binding by the transcriptional activator protein p53 will be determined. The research will also investigate the parameters that define the assembly and activity of complexes containing human RNA polymerase II, general transcription factors, and promoter DNA. Fundamental questions about the macromolecular interactions that govern the onset of transcription will be answered. The results from the research will be integrated with previously published biochemical and cell-based studies to provide a comprehensive view of the mechanism by which HMGB1 functions and how RNA polymerase II complexes assemble and transcribe.

Broader impacts: The future of science is intimately tied to integrating research and education. Graduate and undergraduate students will perform the research in this project, and significant effort will be made in training these students in experimental design, interpretation of data, creative thought, preparation of manuscripts, and oral presentations. Importantly, efforts will continue to be made to recruit underrepresented minority students into the laboratory. The project also contains an educational component. An experimental module for an undergraduate laboratory course will be developed and implemented. It will teach the relationship between fluorescence energy resonance transfer efficiency and distance between fluorophores in a discovery-based experiment emphasizing experimental design, application of acquired knowledge, data interpretation, and literature searches.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

The expression of genes that are encoded by DNA is essential for sustained life. Transcription is the first step in gene expression. During transcription the enzyme RNA polymerase II (Pol II), using DNA as a template, synthesizes mRNA molecules. Necessary for transcribing any gene is forming complexes containing transcription factors and promoter DNA, thereby making it important to decipher how these complexes assemble and what defines their function. The goal of this project was to investigate the assembly mechanism, dynamics, and heterogeneity of human transcription factor/DNA complexes, and how these parameters contribute to transcriptional control. Such an understanding is important because transcription is a principle control point for regulating gene expression during growth, development, and normal cellular metabolism. 

This research took advantage of single-molecule fluorescence techniques. These are experiments that allow scientists to visualize individual molecules during an experiment. This level of resolution allowed us to distinguish differences in the behaviors between molecules and make very rapid measurements of how molecules move. Therefore, single-molecule studies have the potential to reveal the dynamic behavior, conformational states, and heterogeneity of biological complexes, thus providing unprecedented insight into their function.  

We developed a single-molecule system to monitor transcription by human Pol II. The first step in Pol II transcription is the assembly of a preinitiation complex (PIC) on DNA. In addition to Pol II, the PIC contains a set of general transcription factor proteins which help to bring Pol II to the DNA and position it properly for the start of transcription. By visualizing individual DNA molecules within PICs, our experiments allowed us to distinguish between active and inactive complexes. Thus, we were able to determine how different modes of PIC assembly impacted transcriptional activity. We found that the the order in which factors bind to DNA to assemble PICs can impact transcriptional activity. Moreover, the fate of the general transcription factor TFIIB appears to be important for transcriptional activity – the majority of active complexes released TFIIB during early transcription. 

We also used single-molecule experiments to investigate how the human architectural protein HMGB1 interacts with DNA. Architectural proteins facilitate the formation of large protein/DNA complexes important in transcriptional regulation by dynamically binding and bending DNA. We used pieces of HMGB1 and specific mutations in HMGB1 to understand how the protein binds and bends individual molecules of DNA. Uniquely, our approach enabled us to resolve mixed populations of bent and unbent DNA, providing new insight into how this protein functions. We found that HMGB1 can simultaneously use two regions, the A and B boxes, to bind and bend DNA. However, the tail of the protein can act as a damper to control the interaction of the B box with DNA. This identified the C-terminal tail as a regulator of the ability of HMGB1 to modulate the conformational flexibility in the DNA contained within large protein/DNA complexes.

Additional experiments established a single-molecule system to monitor how the transcriptional activator protein p53 binds to and releases from DNA. When p53 binds to DNA it controls the expression of genes important for regulating both cell growth and cell death. Our work will contribute to understanding how p53 regulates these diverse cell fate outcomes. We found that in real time, single molecules of p53 bind to DNA dynamically (rapid on and off). We followed the pathways by which different p53/DNA complexes assembled and disassembled. Our results support a model that a difference exists between p53 dimers that directly bind DNA and dimer/DNA complexes originating from tetramer DNA binding. 

Broader impacts:

The future of science is intimately tied to integrating research and education. Graduate and undergraduate students performed all the research for this project, and significant effort was made to train these students in experimental design, interpretation of data, creative thought, and written and oral communication. All the graduate and undergraduate students that contributed to this project were women, and one was also an underrepresented minority. 

Importantly, the project also contained a specific educational objective. An experimental module for an undergraduate laboratory course was developed and taught to students. The module teaches the widely-utilized biochemical technique of FRET (fluorescence resonance energy transfer) using a discovery-driven format that is interesting for students. The module was taught to over 200 students during the funding period with a very high success rate. The teaching module has been broadly disseminated to the biochemical education community via publication.
